channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: As COVID-19 cases rose, so did diabetes — no one knows why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02322-0

The spike in childhood type 1 diabetes opened new avenues for researchers to explore the cause of the disease.
item.dc:title: As COVID-19 cases rose, so did diabetes — no one knows why
item.dc:creator: Clare Watson

item.title: Dementia risk linked to blood-protein imbalance in middle age
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02374-2

Abnormal levels of certain proteins — many of which have roles outside the brain — could be an early hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease or similar conditions.
item.dc:title: Dementia risk linked to blood-protein imbalance in middle age
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

item.title: Publisher Correction: Geometric frustration of Jahn–Teller order in the infinite-layer lattice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06432-7

Publisher Correction: Geometric frustration of Jahn–Teller order in the infinite-layer lattice
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Geometric frustration of Jahn–Teller order in the infinite-layer lattice
item.dc:creator: Woo Jin Kim

item.title: Ben Franklin: founding father of anti-counterfeiting techniques
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02260-x

The eighteenth-century American patriot developed a host of measures to foil criminals trying to pass fake paper notes.
item.dc:title: Ben Franklin: founding father of anti-counterfeiting techniques

item.title: A lethal fungal infection gets a hand from the body’s own defences
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02259-4

Bloodstream infections by a common fungus are less deadly in mice engineered to have lower levels of a protein secreted by immune cells.
item.dc:title: A lethal fungal infection gets a hand from the body’s own defences

item.title: Sexual harassment in science: tackling abusers, protecting targets, changing cultures
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02363-5

Sarah Batterman describes the personal and professional toll after being targeted at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute. Its director Josh Tewkesbury describes changes after staff spoke out.
item.dc:title: Sexual harassment in science: tackling abusers, protecting targets, changing cultures
item.dc:creator: Adam Levy

item.title: Short arms and lanky legs: the genetic basis of walking on two legs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02345-7

Genome-wide map reveals regions associated with skeletal changes that enabled humans to walk upright.
item.dc:title: Short arms and lanky legs: the genetic basis of walking on two legs
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: All through the night: sleep-deprived scientists share their stories
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02371-5

Nature’s investigation into the sleep of scientists drew a range of responses from our audience.
item.dc:title: All through the night: sleep-deprived scientists share their stories
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: How to create a lab-group logo that stands out from the crowd
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 20 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02358-2

An eye-catching logo says a lot about your lab’s research, workplace culture and collaborative potential. Take time to get it right.
item.dc:title: How to create a lab-group logo that stands out from the crowd
item.dc:creator: Andy Tay

item.title: Author Correction: A highly magnified star at redshift 6.2
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06125-1

Author Correction: A highly magnified star at redshift 6.2
item.dc:title: Author Correction: A highly magnified star at redshift 6.2

Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06413-w

Carbonaceous dust grains seen in the first billion years of cosmic time

item.content:encoded:

Dilemma in optical identification of single-layer multiferroics

Yangliu Wu

Jingxuan Wei

item.title: Disrupting snail food-chain curbs parasitic disease in Senegal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02362-6

Intervention against schistosomiasis also shows agricultural and economic benefits, and the successful launch of India’s Chandrayaan-3 lunar mission.
item.dc:title: Disrupting snail food-chain curbs parasitic disease in Senegal
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Reply to: Dilemma in optical identification of single-layer multiferroics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06108-2

Reply to: Dilemma in optical identification of single-layer multiferroics
item.dc:title: Reply to: Dilemma in optical identification of single-layer multiferroics

item.title: A spatially resolved timeline of the human maternal–fetal interface
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06298-9

A multiomics approach is used to produce a spatiotemporal atlas of the human maternal–fetal interface in the first half of pregnancy, revealing relationships among gestational age, extravillous trophoblasts and spiral artery remodelling.
item.dc:title: A spatially resolved timeline of the human maternal–fetal interface

item.title: p53 governs an AT1 differentiation programme in lung cancer suppression
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06253-8

p53 is shown to have a pivotal role in the differentiation of alveolar type 1 cells in cancer and alveolar repair after injury, and loss of this governance can promote diseases such as lung adenocarcinoma.
item.dc:title: p53 governs an AT1 differentiation programme in lung cancer suppression
item.dc:creator: Alyssa M. Kaiser

item.title: KRAS(G12D) drives lepidic adenocarcinoma through stem-cell reprogramming
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06324-w

A study identifies the AT1 cell as a cell of origin for lung adenocarcinoma, and demonstrates that expression of oncogenic KRAS in differentiated AT1 cells reprograms them back into AT2 stem cells that generate indolent lepidic tumours.
item.dc:title: KRAS(G12D) drives lepidic adenocarcinoma through stem-cell reprogramming
item.dc:creator: Nicholas H. Juul
Jung-Ki Yoon
Marina C. Martinez
Neha Rishi
Yana I. Kazadaeva

Joseph B. Shrager
Rahul Sinha
Tushar J. Desai

item.title: Extreme dynamics in a biomolecular condensate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06329-5

Two highly charged disordered human proteins phase-separate into viscous complex coacervates while retaining their rapid conformational dynamics through pico- to nanosecond exchange of short-lived side-chain interactions.
item.dc:title: Extreme dynamics in a biomolecular condensate
item.dc:creator: Nicola Galvanetto
Miloš T. Ivanović
Aritra Chowdhury
Andrea Sottini
Mark F. Nüesch
Daniel Nettels
Robert B. Best
Benjamin Schuler

item.title: A common allele of HLA is associated with asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06331-x

The human leukocyte antigen allele HLA-B*15:01 is associated with asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection due to pre-existing T cell immunity.
item.dc:title: A common allele of HLA is associated with asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection
item.dc:creator: Danillo G. Augusto

item.title: Autonomous healing of fatigue cracks via cold welding
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06223-0

We report that fatigue cracks in pure metals can undergo intrinsic self-healing; they were observed to heal by crack flank cold welding induced by local stress state and grain boundary migration.
item.dc:title: Autonomous healing of fatigue cracks via cold welding
item.dc:creator: Christopher M. Barr
Ta Duong
Daniel C. Bufford
Zachary Milne
Abhilash Molkeri

Khalid Hattar
Michael J. Demkowicz
Brad L. Boyce

item.title: A rotating white dwarf shows different compositions on its opposite faces
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06171-9

The Zwicky Transient Facility has observed a transitioning white dwarf with two faces, with one side of its atmosphere dominated by hydrogen and the other by helium.
item.dc:title: A rotating white dwarf shows different compositions on its opposite faces
item.dc:creator: Ilaria Caiazzo

item.title: Superconductivity and strong interactions in a tunable moiré quasicrystal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06294-z

A moiré quasicrystal constructed by twisting three layers of graphene with two different twist angles shows high tunability between a periodic-like regime at low energies and a strongly quasiperiodic regime at higher energies alongside strong interactions and superconductivity.
item.dc:title: Superconductivity and strong interactions in a tunable moiré quasicrystal
item.dc:creator: Aviram Uri

item.title: A long-period radio transient active for three decades
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06202-5

The discovery of a long-period radio transient, GPM J1839–10, prompted a search of radio archives, thereby finding that this source has been repeating since at least 1988.
item.dc:title: A long-period radio transient active for three decades

item.title: The global wildland–urban interface
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06320-0

A global assessment shows that the wildland–urban interface occurs on all continents, showing its broad-scale patterns and providing a basis for future research on dynamics and socioeconomic and biophysical processes.
item.dc:title: The global wildland–urban interface
item.dc:creator: Franz Schug
Avi Bar-Massada

Volker C. Radeloff

item.title: Early contact between late farming and pastoralist societies in southeastern Europe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06334-8

Archaeogenetic analysis of 135 individuals from the zone between southeastern Europe and the northwestern Black Sea region indicates contacts between farming and pastoralist populations at the end of the Copper Age.
item.dc:title: Early contact between late farming and pastoralist societies in southeastern Europe
item.dc:creator: Sandra Penske

item.title: RNA polymerase II associates with active genes during DNA replication
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06341-9

Protein complexes containing RNA polymerase II and immature RNA are associated with active genes immediately after replication, suggesting that transmission of active transcriptional states to daughter cells may not require any additional epigenetic bookmarks.
item.dc:title: RNA polymerase II associates with active genes during DNA replication
item.dc:creator: Tyler K. Fenstermaker
Svetlana Petruk
Sina K. Kovermann
Hugh W. Brock
Alexander Mazo

item.title: Diverse modes of H3K36me3-guided nucleosomal deacetylation by Rpd3S
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06349-1

Structural and biochemical studies of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae Rpd3 small complex in free and H3K36me3 nucleosome-bound states reveal multiple nucleosome-binding modes and provide insights into mechanisms underlying epigenetic regulation by histone modification.
item.dc:title: Diverse modes of H3K36me3-guided nucleosomal deacetylation by Rpd3S
item.dc:creator: Haipeng Guan
Pei Wang
Pei Zhang
Chun Ruan
Yutian Ou

Xiangdong Zheng
Jianlin Lei
Bing Li
Chuangye Yan
Haitao Li

item.title: Spin–vibronic coherence drives singlet–triplet conversion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06233-y

Many aspects of materials chemistry rely on singlet–triplet spin conversion, but spin–vibronic effects are shown to accelerate the process when vibronic coupling causes the quantum-mechanical mixing of spin states.
item.dc:title: Spin–vibronic coherence drives singlet–triplet conversion
item.dc:creator: Shahnawaz Rafiq
Nicholas P. Weingartz
Sarah Kromer
Felix N. Castellano
Lin X. Chen

item.title: An atlas of healthy and injured cell states and niches in the human kidney
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05769-3

A high-resolution kidney cellular atlas of 51 main cell types, including rare and previously undescribed cell populations, represents a comprehensive benchmark of cellular states, neighbourhoods, outcome-associated signatures and publicly available interactive visualizations.
item.dc:title: An atlas of healthy and injured cell states and niches in the human kidney

item.title: Mixing of moiré-surface and bulk states in graphite
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06264-5

The electronic states in three-dimensional crystals such as graphite can be tuned by a superlattice potential occurring at the interface with crystallographically aligned hexagonal boron nitride.
item.dc:title: Mixing of moiré-surface and bulk states in graphite
item.dc:creator: Ciaran Mullan
Sergey Slizovskiy

Vladimir I. Fal’ko
Artem Mishchenko

item.title: Mixed-dimensional moiré systems of twisted graphitic thin films
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06290-3

Transport measurements of dual-gated devices constructed by slightly rotating a monolayer graphene sheet atop a thin bulk graphite crystal are performed, showing that moiré potential transforms the electronic properties of an entire graphitic thin film.
item.dc:title: Mixed-dimensional moiré systems of twisted graphitic thin films
item.dc:creator: Dacen Waters
Ellis Thompson
Esmeralda Arreguin-Martinez
Manato Fujimoto
Yafei Ren
Kenji Watanabe
Takashi Taniguchi
Ting Cao
Di Xiao
Matthew Yankowitz

item.title: Mega-scale experimental analysis of protein folding stability in biology and design
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06328-6

Large-scale assays using cDNA display proteolysis are used to measure the folding stabilities of protein domains, providing a method to quantify the effects of mutations on protein folding, with applications in protein design.
item.dc:title: Mega-scale experimental analysis of protein folding stability in biology and design
item.dc:creator: Kotaro Tsuboyama
Justas Dauparas
Jonathan Chen
Elodie Laine
Yasser Mohseni Behbahani
Jonathan J. Weinstein
Niall M. Mangan
Sergey Ovchinnikov
Gabriel J. Rocklin

item.title: Organization of the human intestine at single-cell resolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05915-x

Intestinal cell types are organized into distinct neighbourhoods and communities within the healthy human intestine, with distinct immunological niches.
item.dc:title: Organization of the human intestine at single-cell resolution
item.dc:creator: John W. Hickey
Winston R. Becker

item.title: The complementarity of DDR, nucleic acids and anti-tumour immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06069-6

This Perspective reviews advances in the understanding of the intersection between the DNA damage response and the response to immune checkpoint blockade therapy, and discusses how developments in the field could lead to improved anti-cancer therapies.
item.dc:title: The complementarity of DDR, nucleic acids and anti-tumour immunity
item.dc:creator: Anand V. R. Kornepati
Cody M. Rogers
Patrick Sung
Tyler J. Curiel

item.title: Diverse clonal fates emerge upon drug treatment of homogeneous cancer cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06342-8

Anti-cancer treatment often results in a subset of the clonal cell population developing resistance to therapy, with resistant cells displaying a diversity of fate types resulting from the intrinsic variability among the clonal population before treatment.
item.dc:title: Diverse clonal fates emerge upon drug treatment of homogeneous cancer cells
item.dc:creator: Yogesh Goyal
Gianna T. Busch
Maalavika Pillai

item.title: Indirect effects shape species fitness in coevolved mutualistic networks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06319-7

A numerical analysis of mutualistic interactions between species shows that indirect effects from species they do not interact with directly are the biggest source of variation and cause the largest decreases to species fitness.
item.dc:title: Indirect effects shape species fitness in coevolved mutualistic networks
item.dc:creator: Leandro G. Cosmo
Ana Paula A. Assis
Marcus A. M. de Aguiar
Mathias M. Pires
Alfredo Valido
Pedro Jordano
John N. Thompson
Jordi Bascompte
Paulo R. Guimarães Jr

item.title: Molecular features driving cellular complexity of human brain evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06338-4

A single-cell genomics analysis of humans, chimpanzees and rhesus macaques reveals the molecular features that drive cellular and regulatory complexity of human brain evolution.
item.dc:title: Molecular features driving cellular complexity of human brain evolution
item.dc:creator: Emre Caglayan
Fatma Ayhan
Yuxiang Liu
Rachael M. Vollmer
Emily Oh
Chet C. Sherwood
Todd M. Preuss
Soojin V. Yi
Genevieve Konopka

item.title: A cell-type-specific error-correction signal in the posterior parietal cortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06357-1

A molecularly defined subset of somatostatin-positive inhibitory neurons in the mouse posterior parietal cortex carries a cell-type-specific error-correction signal for navigation.
item.dc:title: A cell-type-specific error-correction signal in the posterior parietal cortex
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Green
Carissa A. Bruno
Lisa Traunmüller
Jennifer Ding
Siniša Hrvatin
Daniel E. Wilson
Thomas Khodadad
Jonathan Samuels
Michael E. Greenberg
Christopher D. Harvey

item.title: Had COVID but no symptoms? You might have this genetic mutation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02318-w

A common variant in an immune-system gene is linked with a much higher chance of dodging symptoms after SARS-CoV-2 infection.
item.dc:title: Had COVID but no symptoms? You might have this genetic mutation
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Slow-beating radio waves from a long-lived source
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02295-0

Astronomers have uncovered a source of radio waves that pulsate more slowly than expected. Meticulous records reveal that the emission has been detected for decades, highlighting the remarkable foresight of scientists in bygone years.
item.dc:title: Slow-beating radio waves from a long-lived source
item.dc:creator: Victoria M. Kaspi

item.title: The global fight for critical minerals is costly and damaging
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02330-0

Elements such as rare-earth metals are crucial for the clean-energy transition. Sustainability, equity and security are all at risk in the rush to break China’s dominance over their production.
item.dc:title: The global fight for critical minerals is costly and damaging

item.title: A pink rover tackles the red planet — and barriers for women in science
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02344-8

An Australian team designed the eye-catching robot to spark conversations about diversity in engineering and robotics.
item.dc:title: A pink rover tackles the red planet — and barriers for women in science
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: When we become stars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02351-9

The safety catch.
item.dc:title: When we become stars
item.dc:creator: Simon Pan

item.title: Dynamics of protein droplets revealed by bridging multiple scales
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02215-2

Many biological processes rely on proteins that aggregate into droplets governed by dynamics that span myriad scales. A clever combination of spectroscopy and simulation offers a way to probe these diverse dynamics.
item.dc:title: Dynamics of protein droplets revealed by bridging multiple scales
item.dc:creator: Marina G. Guenza

item.title: Oil from the Amazon? Proposal to drill at river’s mouth worries researchers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02187-3

Energy firm Petrobras says any leaked oil would not reach the Brazilian coast, but scientists are concerned about a vast reef nearby.
item.dc:title: Oil from the Amazon? Proposal to drill at river’s mouth worries researchers
item.dc:creator: Meghie Rodrigues

item.title: A genetic basis for asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02102-w

A common genetic variant of the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) complex, a family of genes involved in the immune response, is associated with an absence of symptoms during SARS-CoV-2 infection. Previous exposure to cold viruses seems to confer this immunity.
item.dc:title: A genetic basis for asymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection

item.title: Cell-level reference maps for the human body take shape
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01817-0

The HuBMAP consortium has generated spatially resolved cell atlases for the human intestine, kidney and placenta, which enable analysis of tissue organization in unprecedented detail.
item.dc:title: Cell-level reference maps for the human body take shape
item.dc:creator: Roser Vento-Tormo
Roser Vilarrasa-Blasi

item.title: Daily briefing: Why your department should throw a party
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02364-4

How to throw a simple celebratory gathering to help students and staff to reflect on their accomplishments. Plus, the true cost of science’s language barrier for non-native English speakers, and a mammal wrestles a dinosaur in an extraordinary fossil.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why your department should throw a party
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Expeditions in post-war Colombia have found hundreds of new species. But rich ecosystems are now under threat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02300-6

Since Colombia’s peace agreement opened the country up, scientists have been racing to study its riches before it’s too late.
item.dc:title: Expeditions in post-war Colombia have found hundreds of new species. But rich ecosystems are now under threat
item.dc:creator: Aisling Irwin

item.title: Cell ‘atlases’ offer unprecedented view of placenta, intestines and kidneys
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02348-4

Organ mapping studies show how kidney cells become diseased, and how cells from a fetus invade and remodel blood vessels in the lining of the uterus.
item.dc:title: Cell ‘atlases’ offer unprecedented view of placenta, intestines and kidneys
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: The particle-physics breakthrough that paved the way for the Higgs boson
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02296-z

The discovery of ‘weak neutral currents’ at Europe’s particle-physics research centre CERN 50 years ago was a decisive step towards establishing the standard model of particle physics — a journey that continues to this day.
item.dc:title: The particle-physics breakthrough that paved the way for the Higgs boson
item.dc:creator: Pippa Wells

item.title: Protein folding stability measured at scale
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02105-7

Protein sequences vary widely in their folding stabilities (the energetic favourability of folded compared with unfolded conformations), and protein alterations that affect stability have profound effects on evolution, health and disease, and biotechnological applications. An innovative method has made it possible to measure these stabilities on a massive scale, revealing evolutionary trends and opening up possibilities for machine learning.
item.dc:title: Protein folding stability measured at scale

item.title: Can India’s new billion-dollar funding agency boost research?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02336-8

India’s proposed National Research Foundation will shake up the scientific landscape to encourage a culture of research.
item.dc:title: Can India’s new billion-dollar funding agency boost research?
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Tissue-regeneration program underlies lung-cancer suppression
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02025-6

How the protein p53 suppresses lung cancer, the most common cause of cancer deaths worldwide, has remained unclear. It has been found that p53 impedes the development of lung cancer by promoting a highly specific cell-differentiation program that is characteristic of normal tissue regeneration after an injury.
item.dc:title: Tissue-regeneration program underlies lung-cancer suppression

item.title: Rings of fire: centuries of tree growth show wildfires increasing in Vietnam
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02235-y

The data suggest human activities are more to blame for the increase than climate change.
item.dc:title: Rings of fire: centuries of tree growth show wildfires increasing in Vietnam
item.dc:creator: Jude Coleman

item.title: Quantum sensors: detect heart disease sooner
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02247-8

Quantum sensors: detect heart disease sooner
item.dc:title: Quantum sensors: detect heart disease sooner
item.dc:creator: Bettina Heidecker

item.title: Industry: a poor record for whistle-blowers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02245-w

Industry: a poor record for whistle-blowers
item.dc:title: Industry: a poor record for whistle-blowers
item.dc:creator: Nancy F. Olivieri
Morteza Mahmoudi

item.title: Brazil: threat to Indigenous peoples persists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02302-4

Brazil: threat to Indigenous peoples persists
item.dc:title: Brazil: threat to Indigenous peoples persists
item.dc:creator: André Faria Mendonça

item.title: Monitor changes to ice-bound nuclear fallout in Antarctica
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02246-9

Monitor changes to ice-bound nuclear fallout in Antarctica
item.dc:title: Monitor changes to ice-bound nuclear fallout in Antarctica
item.dc:creator: Krystyna M. Saunders
Karina T. Meredith

item.title: How a simple celebratory gathering can offer a positive outlook
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02350-w

My research area in the biological sciences department has a simple end-of-semester ceremony that helps us to share our successes, writes Ilinca Ciubotariu.
item.dc:title: How a simple celebratory gathering can offer a positive outlook
item.dc:creator: Ilinca Ciubotariu

item.title: From the archive: computer security, and a key experiment by Pascal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02294-1

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: computer security, and a key experiment by Pascal

item.title: How to educate the world: prioritize funding and data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02327-9

Data gaps are hindering progress on the Sustainable Development Goal for education and lifelong learning. Modest funding will help to fill them.
item.dc:title: How to educate the world: prioritize funding and data

item.title: The true cost of science’s language barrier for non-native English speakers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02320-2

Survey quantifies the extra time that researchers whose first language isn’t English need to read, write and present data.
item.dc:title: The true cost of science’s language barrier for non-native English speakers
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Water pollution ‘timebomb’ threatens global health
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02337-7

Simulations predict a water-pollution crisis by the end of the century.
item.dc:title: Water pollution ‘timebomb’ threatens global health
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer

item.title: Daily briefing: The chemist who survived thallium poisoning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02359-1

The terrifying and life-changing experience of thallium poisoning. Plus, taking part in genetic studies might be in your genes, and medicine’s problem with flawed and fake data.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: The chemist who survived thallium poisoning
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: EU proposal on CRISPR-edited crops is welcome — but not enough
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02328-8

The door should be opened further: CRISPR has huge potential to boost food security in the face of pathogens and climate change.
item.dc:title: EU proposal on CRISPR-edited crops is welcome — but not enough
item.dc:creator: Devang Mehta

item.title: Medicine is plagued by untrustworthy clinical trials. How many studies are faked or flawed?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02299-w

Investigations suggest that, in some fields, at least one-quarter of clinical trials might be problematic or even entirely made up, warn some researchers. They urge stronger scrutiny.
item.dc:title: Medicine is plagued by untrustworthy clinical trials. How many studies are faked or flawed?
item.dc:creator: Richard Van Noorden

item.title: OBOX regulates murine zygotic genome activation and early development
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06428-3

OBOX regulates murine zygotic genome activation and early development
item.dc:title: OBOX regulates murine zygotic genome activation and early development

item.title: My glacier is melting — and I’m charting its decline
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02308-y

Glaciologist Andrea Fischer describes her first-hand experience of studying these ever-changing ice masses.
item.dc:title: My glacier is melting — and I’m charting its decline
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: To save bears, we must learn to live alongside them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02301-5

With urban areas expanding and climate change shrinking bears’ habitats, the animals’ interactions with humans will make — or break — efforts to preserve their populations.
item.dc:title: To save bears, we must learn to live alongside them
item.dc:creator: Henry Nicholls

item.title: Do you take part in genetic studies? That might be in your genes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02309-x

Findings could help researchers to better understand ‘participation bias’ in studies that link genomics with health, behaviour and other traits.
item.dc:title: Do you take part in genetic studies? That might be in your genes
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Sleeping embryonic genomes are awoken by OBOX proteins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01618-5

Activation of gene transcription is precisely regulated in early embryos. The identification of key transcription factors now shows how the transcription machinery is guided to the right place at the right time in mice.
item.dc:title: Sleeping embryonic genomes are awoken by OBOX proteins
item.dc:creator: Edlyn Wu
Nadine L. Vastenhouw

item.title: Daily briefing: Why aspartame is a possible carcinogen
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02347-5

The WHO has classified the sweetener aspartame as ‘possibly carcinogenic’, the same category as aloe vera extracts and red meat. Plus, the evidence of how mining might affect enigmatic deep-sea ecosystems.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why aspartame is a possible carcinogen
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Alzheimer’s drug donanemab helps most when taken at earliest disease stage, study finds
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 17 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02321-1

But the drug, an antibody that attacks the protein amyloid, does not work as well in people with more advanced disease.
item.dc:title: Alzheimer’s drug donanemab helps most when taken at earliest disease stage, study finds
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon
